chapter.title: SpamGuard
chapter.para:
The SpamGuard Appliance is identified by the
symbol. The SpamGuard Appliance works to filter email for Spam. Email transported by the SMTP, POP, and IMAP protocols can be scanned for the presence of spam.
The SpamGuard Appliance is a Software Appliance , which can be installed into multiple Virtual Racks. For more information on configuring policies and Software Appliances, please refer to .

sect1.title: Administrative Interface
sect1.para: The interface for SpamGuard is presented as four tabs. The first three tabs are for the different email protocols that ⪚ can scan. The last tab allows administrators to view events (see ).

sect2.title: SMTP Tab
sect2.para: The SMTP tab controls how the ⪚ handles emails transported over the SMTP protocol. Contents of this tab is shown in .

There are five properties associated with configuring SMTP incoming/outgoing scanning, as shown in . Detailed explanation of these follows.
source
The source of the email message. The value incomming message refers to messages entering your network via SMTP. This implies that there is an SMTP Server within your protected network. The value outgoing message refers to SMTP messages is originating from within your protected network. This could either be from your internal SMTP server or desktop SMTP clients.
scan
This checkbox controls scanning for the given source. When the box is checked, this means that the ⪚ will scan email for spam in that direction.
scan strength
This controls the sensitivity of the spam scanner. There are 5 possible values ranging from very high to very log.
The value very high means most sensitive to spam. Setting the scan strength to very high will cause the greatest percentage of your mail to be considered spam.
action if SPAM detected
This controls what actions ⪚ should take on the message itself, should the message be determined to be spam. There are four possible values.
mark message causes the email message to have its subject changed to start with the phrase [SPAM].... Users can then set-up email client filter rules to cause such messages to be placed in special folders.
pass message causes the message to be passed on to the recipient, even though it was detected as spam.
block message causes the message to be blocked, meaning the sender believes it was delivered yet it was never forwarded to the recipient. Although neither sender nor recipient know the message was blocked, it will still be noted in the Event Log
quarantine message causes the message to be quarantined. For more information on the operation of this feature, please refer to
notification if SPAM detected
This controls any notifications. Notifications are net-new emails, stating that a spam message was detected at your ⪚. There are two possible values.
notify sender causes an email to be sent to the original sender of the email, informing them that they sent spam.
This feature should only be used for cases when you know the sender should not be sending spam. An example is a spam email originating from within your protected network. Such an email coming from the desktop of one of your company's employees would likely be the result of a worm or other virus.
do not notify causes no notification messages to be sent.

sect2.title: Events Tab
sect2.para: The Events tab contents is shown in .
The Events Tab is another implementation of an Event Log, as described in . The complete list of columns and their meaning is as follows.

listitem.para: The time the event took place
The action taken on the mail. The value depends on the mail protocol, but will contain descriptive text such as block or mark.
The client IP Address of the protocol client. Recall that for SMTP this is the sender of the mail, and for IMAP/POP the receiver of the mail.
The subject of the email. This may be blank if the email had no subject.
The recipient email address of the email.
The sender of the email. Note that for spam, this is frequently blank.
This is the score applied to the email by the spam scanner. Higher values indicate more likely to be spam.

This value is either inbound or outbound, and describes the direction of message flow. For example, if the protocol was SMTP and this value is inbound, then the SMTP server is within the protected network and the client outside. For IMAP/POP, inbound would indicate the client was within the protected network.
The server IP Address. Recall that for SMTP this is the machine receiving the email, and for IMAP/POP the machine holding the inbox.

question.para: Why is blocking (or quarantining) of emails when spam detected not always an option?

answer.para: Only the SMTP protocol allows the ⪚ to block mails. The details of the POP and IMAP protocols prevent them from being blocked or quarantined.

question.para: When configuring my ⪚ to mark spam received over IMAP, the subject of the mails changes to [SPAM]... only after I click on the message. Why?

answer.para: Most IMAP clients first fetch summary information about emails (subject, sender) so the end user can see a preview list of messages. Only when the user selects (clicks on) the message is the actual content of the message retreived from the server. It is then that the ⪚ is able to scan the message. Unfortunatly, some email clients do not detect the change in subject and update their preview list.

question.para: Why is Subject (or sender) blank for some emails in the Event Log?

answer.para: Not all emails (especially spam emails) have subjects. Some spammers also use tricks to cause there to be no detectable sender.
